import React, {Component} from "react" import styled from 'styled-components' class Divvy extends Component { render(){ return (

Divvy Case Study

Designing an app that will encourage Gen Z users to keep track of money usage


Introduction
Context

This design project was done as a final evaluation for my Launch UX course where I was taught basic UX principles and had the ability to practice them alingside my peers. I collaborated with Tien Tran, a friend and another student in the course, to bring this idea to life entirely remotely which was another interesting aspect to this project. This case study will take you through this process and summarize what we learned as realatively new designers.

Problem Statement

"How might we design a web and mobile app that allows Gen Z college students to create a monthly budget and track their spending?" Our problems statement was one that we were able to pick out of 4 others to complete this project. We chose this one since it was dear to our hearts as Gen Z students entering the world of adulthood and soon having to handle our own budgets.


Research
Observing the current market

When thinking about how we wanted to approach this issue we looked first for inspiration and how companies were solving this problem currently. There are many apps that have been made to help users better keep track of their money, we deciding to focus on Buddy and EveryDollar. We picked these apps because it had similar functionality and aesthertics to what we wanted in out final app. The problem was that we could not directly use these apps as a template as they were not catered to out specific user class which in this case is Gen Z college students. We mainly used these apps as a reference to certain technical functionality and actions that may be applicable in our case.

User interviews

While it is clear that we are the exact target user for our problem statement, it was still important to separate our preferences and ideas of what a good budgeting app can be to get a wider idea of what Gen Z students think. We conducted both ethnographic and non-directed interviews from students ranging from 19-22 as well as recently graduated alumni as we thought it help us get a sense of what a person who has already transistioned into the real world financially wouldve wanted help with through this product.

Ethnographic: we conducted these using the two apps mentioned earlier, Buddy and EveryDollar. We wanted to see how our target users navigate these apps and which actions were intutive. Ultimately we wated to learn which features were benificial for us to learn from and which features we could improve on.
Questions:
Buddy mobile app
Can you show me how you would create a new budget? Can you add random numbers for the categories you use in real life? Can you remove categories that don’t apply to you? Can you add me as a member of this budget? Can you show me how you would log a transaction? Can you change income to 3,000? Can you flip to a different week? What features did you find most useful? Would you or would you not use this app and why?
Every dollar app
Could you show me how to make a new budget for August? Could you walk me through the process of adding an item to the food category? Could you walk me through submitting a transaction? Could you show me how you would change your income amount? Could you show me how you would delete an item? Could you show me how you would make the church item a monthly item? Could you walk me through how you would set a due date for an item.


The main takeaways that we got from doing these interviews were that the structure of these apps was intuitive, especially when the goals were adding a transaction and creating a budget for various lengths. We also found that some buttons and the way they were displayed did not relay the correct message to users, this allowed us to be more cautious of what icons we used as well as making sure everything looks clickable. Something we found interesting was that each user had a different way they navigate and perform certain actions, for example, delete, some user found a button that helped them perform the actions while some opted for swiping on an item and deleting through there. Ultimately when asked whether they would use the apps most people said no because it does what an excel sheet would do or its more convenient to keep mental notes. This got us thinking about a subproblem to our problem statement, how could we make this app more meaningful for gen z students to use and that would be better integrated into their lifestyle.

Non-directed interviews: Alongside the ethnographic interviews we also conducted 4 non-directed interviews with the purpose of understanding the core reasons why college students save and if not, why that is. We wanted to get a better grasp of the user mindset to better create something that will be useful in their lives. The questions asked here were also open-ended and broad. Some of the best insight we got wasn’t even from these questions but from the conversations and stories that came about from them. Non-directed questions: How do you normally budget your money? Have you used any tools to help? If so explain When was the last time you had to save up for something or to pay off something? What did you do to meet this goal? What are some key factors that go into making your budget? (like rent, water, etc.) Can you list out your monthly/yearly expenses from most priority to least? why? What are your main reasons for keeping a budget? How far in advance do you budget? Is there any particular reason for this? From these questions, we were able to understand users’ current habits and how those came to be. We also used these questions as a bridge to allow users to share personal stories of money in their lives and how it was handled growing up. Some things we found insightful in these conversations included that many people use their bank apps to keep track of money since they deem it trustworthy and convenient for tracking expenses on their card. Another insight is that the students we interviewed, many had their parents take care of finances for them, being a “good spender” is something that they were never taught. The way parents would help them budget when growing up included a golden rule of not spending money when they don’t need to instead of providing healthy spending habits. Finally, many students felt more inclined to keep track of money if they had goals and persistent guidance since it was never an active part of their life before.

Wireframe

Prototype

Usability testing

Takeways
); } } export default Divvy;
